Edison Elementary
August 4 at 10:37 AM ·

Good morning parents. I want to clear up some confusion about class lists and teachers. When we were originally scheduled to start school on August 10th I had told my teachers to start making contact with students the last week in July. Some were sending letters, others making phone calls, some reaching our through Facebook. As the summer progressed more parents were choosing our online platform. Then our School Board voted to delay the start of school until August 31st. At that point I told teachers to wait to reach out to parents as I was having to shuffle class lists around. For example in 2nd grade I currently have one teacher with 16 students and another with 22. I try to balance the classes as much as possible. If you haven't heard anything yet, please don't take this in a negative way. The teachers are excited and ready to see your child. I hope to have a solid list soon and I promise you will hear from your child's teacher. If you still haven't heard anything by August 20th please call me at Edison 918 367 5521. As always I'm available to answer your questions.

All eighth-graders in the 2019-20 school year will receive this exemption.… More

There is an emergency state school board meeting at 4:00 PM today. One of the agenda items is a vote to possibly close all schools in the state of Oklahoma until April 6th. We will continue to monitor the situation and make decisions to ensure the safety of our students and staff members as soon as possible. We have currently suspended all activities and the Home Alone Program until further notice.

Please remain calm and be patient with us as we work to make the best decisions possible during this unfortunate situation.

Brian Burden dedicated 27 1/2 years to educating and building relationships with students across Oklahoma. Bristow was blessed to have Brian serve as our HS assistant principal from 2012-2013 and our MS principal from 2013-2020. His presence at our schools had a profound effect on the students, staff, faculty, and all who encountered him throughout his service.

The BPS Board of Education has approved the creation of the Brian Burden Memorial Scholarship Fund. This scholarship will be awarded to a deserving BHS graduating senior who is planning on pursuing a degree in education.

If you would like to donate and help us continue Brian's lifelong mission of helping students succeed, please send all contributions to:
The Brian Burden Memorial Scholarship Fund
c/o Bristow Public Schools
420 N Main Street
Bristow, OK 74010

All donations will be managed by the Bristow Education Foundation. We thank everyone for their continued support.

LINKING LEARNING TO LIFE

BHS will be hosting a senior seminar for all BHS senior students on Feb. 19th! Students will be learning about important "adulting" topics to help them as they transition from high school to the real world. Breakout session will include learning about insurance, healthcare, vehicle maintenance, money management, interview skills, filing taxes, credit awareness, banking basics, renting/real estate, and many more topics. Several industries will also be in attendance for those interested in going to the work force after graduation.

Seniors have also been completing a Dave Ramsey twelve week financial literacy course, researching careers and opportunities according to their interests, and working on local scholarships.

November has been Native American Month, and the BPS students have honored the Native American culture all month long with various activities.

Students visited Woolaroc and attended an OKC Thunder game for Native American Heritage Day. Collins and Edison hosted a Native American Museum, and MS and HS classes sampled Native American Grape Dumplings and a traditional corn dish known as "pashofa" to Chickasaw/Choctaw and "sofke" to the Creeks. Throughout the month, all sites shared a word in one of the 5 Civilized Tribes' language each day during announcements. Students earned rewards when they remembered the word, its meaning, and what tribe it originated from.

Thank you to everyone that helped our students honor Native Americans and their rich culture and history throughout the month. For more information about our JOM program, follow the Bristow Pirate JOM Program Facebook page at this link: https://www.facebook.com/BristowJOM/.

Today is National Custodian Day, and we would like to take the time to appreciate our BPS custodial staff.

These hardworking individuals arrive at the school long before the teachers and students get out of bed, and they stay long after everyone has left for the day. They have to deal with some of the worst, unimaginable situations, and they do it all with a smile.

They love our kids. They will stop their work and give the students hugs or high-fives; some have even been known to sneak candy to the students when the teachers aren't looking. They also will dress in costumes and play right along with whatever the students dream up. We would not be able to do our jobs without this staff, and we appreciate all you do.

More pictures in the comments!
